title.narrative: Advocacy for Sustainable and Inclusive Palm Oil Sourcing

description.narrative: In 2019, Solidaridad focused its advocacy in the Palm Oil supply chain on the design of European regulatory frameworks (i.e. legislation). Solidardad also submitted input to the consultation for the EU strategy to reduce deforestation and co-developed a letter to Dutch government stimulating them to push the European Commission to develop concrete and time bound action plans. Solidaridad participated in other initiatives, networks and dialogues to stimulate the uptake of sustainable palm oil in Europe. For example, we joined the European Sustainable Palm Oil Choice initiative. The UK Government launched the Global Resource Initiative (GRI), a new cross-government (Defra, BEIS and DfID) and cross-industry initiative that aims to establish the UK as a leader on supply chain sustainability. Solidaridad also corporates to take responsibility beyond their own sourcing and co-invest in sustainable (landscape) solutions. To promote this we presented four opportunities at the FONAP General Assembly. A fact sheet was developed to share the good practice developed in the Henkel partnership with TFA and GCF.

1) Smallholder inclusiveness:
Solidaridad actively advocates for a new approach to sustainability that is inclusive of smallholders and that makes business sense from both the supply and demand side.
As Solidaridad's position on smallholder inclusive palm oil supply chains is becoming more and more recognised by public and private parties in the sector, we receive increasing requests for our expertise. For instance, Solidaridad was invited to a brainstorm session by the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs regarding a MoU with Malaysia on Sustainable Palm Oil and has chaired the panel on smallholders during the RSPO Annual Round Table meeting and the annual linking and learning event. In addition, companies such as Shell, Procter & Gamble, Reckitt Benckiser and Sainsbury's have asked us to think along in the development of their strategy on inclusive palm oil. Henkel has adopted a progressive policy based on Solidaridad's recommendations and is committed to invest beyond their own supply chain in those places where the problems are the most difficult. These developments show that the role of Solidaridad in the policy process has shifted from merely putting smallholder inclusion on the agenda to guiding the implementation of solutions to address the issue.
2) Engagement with MSPO / ISPO: To transform the palm oil value chain, a government-to-government dialogue as well as local initiatives on the ground are needed. The RSPO acts as an important community of change in the sector and is broadly supported. For Solidaridad, this is an important platform to influence strategy development.

comment.narrative: Smallholder strategy for RSPO: the most significant achievement in 2017 was the approval of the RSPO strategy on smallholders by the Board of Governors, which had been under development since November 2015. The first result of this new strategy is that for the first time in the history of RSPO, during the Review of the Principles and Criteria for sustainable palm oil, separate attention was given to smallholder interests. This is the result of increasing awareness among companies and governments on the need to include smallholders in the transition towards a sustainable palm sector. That Solidaridad has played a key role in the development of the strategy is evident from the fact that our key recommendations to improve smallholder inclusion (ensure RSPO contributes to improved livelihoods, simplify criteria for certification of smallholders, and increase the benefits of certification) were taken as the three main objectives of the strategy. Since all European and national initiatives for sustainable palm oil, including ESPO, DASPO, FONAP and BASPO follow the RSPO Principles and Criteria, the adoption of the strategy is of major strategic importance to advance the inclusion of smallholder oil palm growers in the sector.

comment.narrative: We played an active role in the (set-up of the) NGO coalition to lobby for sustainable palm oil legislation - together with NGOs like Greenpeace, Oxfam, Both Ends, Tropenbos, WWF and IUCN. This NGO coalition submitted a letter to Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Agriculture, Economic Affairs and Finance and in a follow-up conversation with the government, the NGO coalition was asked to provide advice on the design of sustainable palm oil legislation.
